member.name: T:NMemcached.Client.ServerConnection
member.summary: A base class for a connection to a single memcached server

remarks.para: The ServerConnection is a more specialized MemcachedConnection that represents a connection to a single Memcached server. The connections that communicate on the text and binary Memcached protocols both inherit from ServerConnection.

member.name: T:NMemcached.Client.MemcachedConnection
member.summary: A base class for creating a connection to Memcached.

remarks.para: MemcachedConnection is the abstract base class for connections to Memcached servers. It is not intended to be represetative of a single server connection but an abstraction of the operations required to interact with Memcached.

Special Note: The predefined subclasses of MemcachedConnection do not allow for expirations greater than 30 days. The Memcached documentation states that expiration durations greater than 30 days are treated as Unix timestamps, but this is not the observed behavior. Memcached uses Unix timestamps no matter the expiration time and certain implementations will throw exceptoins if the expiration time is greater than 30 days.

The MemcachedConnection class supports the folowing cache operations:
Storage Commands
Add Inserts a key/value pair into the cache if the data does not already exist.
Append Adds data to the end of an existing cache entry.
Check and Set (CAS) Stores data for an existing key only if it has not been updated since the last get operation.
Prepend Adds data to the begining of an existing cache entry.
Replace Replaces the value of an existing cache entry with new data.
Set Inserts an item into the cache overwriting any existing entry with the same key.
Retrieval Commands
Get Reads one or more entries from the cache.
GetWitDetail Reads one or more entries from the cache with additional details about the cache entry.
Other Commands
Delete Removes an item from the cache.
Decrement Reduces a numeric cache entry by a specified amount.
Flush Removes all entries from the cache.
FlushAll Removes all entries from the cache after a specified delay.
Increment Increases a numeric cache entry by a specified amount.

member.name: T:Common.Logging.ILog
member.summary: A simple logging interface abstracting logging APIs.

remarks.para: Implementations should defer calling a message's until the message really needs to be logged to avoid performance penalties.

Each log method offers to pass in a instead of the actual message. Using this style has the advantage to defer possibly expensive message argument evaluation and formatting (and formatting arguments!) until the message gets actually logged. If the message is not logged at all (e.g. due to settings), you won't have to pay the peformance penalty of creating the message.

member.author: Mark Pollack
Bruno Baia
Erich Eichinger

member.name: T:Common.Logging.ConfigurationSectionHandler
member.summary: Used in an application's configuration file (App.Config or Web.Config) to configure the logging subsystem.
member.example:
An example configuration section that writes log messages to the Console using the built-in Console Logger.
<configuration> <configSections> <sectionGroup name="common"> <section name="logging" type="Common.Logging.ConfigurationSectionHandler, Common.Logging" /> </sectionGroup> </configSections> <common> <logging> <factoryAdapter type="Common.Logging.Simple.ConsoleOutLoggerFactoryAdapter, Common.Logging"> <arg key="showLogName" value="true" /> <arg key="showDataTime" value="true" /> <arg key="level" value="ALL" /> <arg key="dateTimeFormat" value="yyyy/MM/dd HH:mm:ss:fff" /> </factoryAdapter> </logging> </common> </configuration>

member.name: T:NMemcached.Client.MemcachedClient
member.summary: A Memcached connection that communicates with multiple memcached servers

remarks.para: The methods in this class do not make any assumptions about the server connection implementations. Each method inherited from the MemcachedConnection class are implemented in a way that calls the corresponding method in the underlying server connections.

member.summary: Closes all connections to Memcached servers

member.name: M:NMemcached.Client.MemcachedClient.Create
member.summary: Creates a new MemcachedClient from the application configuration
member.returns: A new MemcachedClient defined by the application configuration

remarks.para: A MemcachedClient instance can be created using settings read from the applicaiton or web configuration file. The built-in configuration uses the included connection provider and does not have the ability to use custom connection providers.
Example:
remarks.code: <configSections> <section name="nmemcached.client" type="NMemcached.Client.Configuration.NMemcachedConfigurationSection, NMemcached.Client" /> </configSections> <nmemcached.client xmlns="http://memcached.protectedvoid.com/2011/06/configuration"> <connectionProvider> <add server="localhost" compressionAlgorithm="Deflate" /> <add server="someRemoteServer" port="15455" compressionAlgorithm="GZip" /> </connectionProvider> </nmemcached.client>
remarks.para: Note: An XSD is in the source tree and included with the binary distributions for intellisense.
The ConnectionProvider element has an optional "hashAlgorithm" attribute that specifies the algorithm to use for they consistent hashing algorithm. The possible values are:

item.description: The FNV algorithm that produces a 32 bit hash value
The FNV1a algorithm that produces a 32 bit hash value
The FNV algorithm that produces a 64 bit hash value
The FNV1a algorithm that produces a 64 bit hash value
The MD5 algorithm that produces a 128 bit hash value
The SHA1 algorithm that produces a 160 bit hash value
The SHA1 algorithm that produces a 256 bit hash value
The SHA1 algorithm that produces a 384 bit hash value
The SHA1 algorithm that produces a 512 bit hash value

remarks.para: Each "add" child element of "connectionProvider" represents a single Memcached server. The only required attribute is the "server" attribute that must contian the host name ir IP address of the destination. Any combination of optional attributes can be provided to configure individual server connections:

item.description: A valid TCP/UDP port number. (default: "11211")
The Memcached communication protocol. Valid values are "text" and "binary". (default: "text")
The transport protocol for the connection. Valid values are "tcp", "udp", "connectionOriented", "connectionless". (default: "tcp")
Determines if data compression is used for items sent to the cache. (default: "false")
The algorithm to use for data compression if "useCompression" is set to "true". Valid values are "GZip" and "Deflate". (default: "GZip")
The character encoding of the data sent to the cache. Value values are "ASCII", "BigEndianUnicode", "Unicode", "UTF32", "UTF7", and "UTF8". (default: "UTF8")
The character encoding of the memcached protocol. Valid values are the same as the payloadEncoding attribute. (default: "UTF8")
The number of milliseconds to wait to send data before throwing an exception. (default: 5000)
The number of milliseconds to wait to receive data before throwing an exception. (default: 5000)

summary.para: There are a variety of logging implementations for .NET currently in use, log4net, Enterprise Library Logging, NLog, to name the most popular. The downside of having differerent implementation is that they do not share a common interface and therefore impose a particular logging implementation on the users of your library. To solve this dependency problem the Common.Logging library introduces a simple abstraction to allow you to select a specific logging implementation at runtime.
The library is based on work done by the developers of IBatis.NET and it's usage is inspired by log4net. Many thanks to the developers of those projects!
The core logging library Common.Logging provides the base logging interface as well as the global that you use to instrument your code:

To output the information logged, you need to tell Common.Logging, what underlying logging system to use. Common.Logging already includes simple console and trace based logger implementations usable out of the box. Adding the following configuration snippet to your app.config causes Common.Logging to output all information to the console:
summary.code:
<configuration> <configSections> <sectionGroup name="common"> <section name="logging" type="Common.Logging.ConfigurationSectionHandler, Common.Logging" /> </sectionGroup> </configSections>
<common> <logging> <factoryAdapter type="Common.Logging.Simple.ConsoleOutLoggerFactoryAdapter, Common.Logging"> <arg key="level" value="DEBUG" /> </factoryAdapter> </logging> </common> </configuration>
summary.para: In the case you want to integrate your own logging system that is not supported by Common.Logging yet, it is easily possible to implement your own plugin by implementing . For convenience there is a base implementation available that usually makes implementing your own adapter a breeze.
If your code already uses the .NET framework's built-in System.Diagnostics.Trace system, you can use to redirect all trace output to the Common.Logging infrastructure.

remarks.para: An AsynchMemcachedClient instance can be created using settings read from the applicaiton or web configuration file. The built-in configuration uses the included connection provider and does not have the ability to use custom connection providers.
Example:
remarks.code: <configSections> <section name="nmemcached.client" type="NMemcached.Client.Configuration.NMemcachedConfigurationSection, NMemcached.Client" /> </configSections> <nmemcached.client xmlns="http://memcached.protectedvoid.com/2011/06/configuration"> <connectionProvider> <add server="localhost" compressionAlgorithm="Deflate" /> <add server="someRemoteServer" port="15455" compressionAlgorithm="GZip" /> </connectionProvider> </nmemcached.client>
remarks.para: Note: An XSD is in the source tree and included with the binary distributions for intellisense.
The ConnectionProvider element has an optional "hashAlgorithm" attribute that specifies the algorithm to use for they consistent hashing algorithm. The possible values are:

item.description: The FNV algorithm that produces a 32 bit hash value
The FNV1a algorithm that produces a 32 bit hash value
The FNV algorithm that produces a 64 bit hash value
The FNV1a algorithm that produces a 64 bit hash value
The MD5 algorithm that produces a 128 bit hash value
The SHA1 algorithm that produces a 160 bit hash value
The SHA1 algorithm that produces a 256 bit hash value
The SHA1 algorithm that produces a 384 bit hash value
The SHA1 algorithm that produces a 512 bit hash value

remarks.para: Each "add" child element of "connectionProvider" represents a single Memcached server. The only required attribute is the "server" attribute that must contian the host name ir IP address of the destination. Any combination of optional attributes can be provided to configure individual server connections:

item.description: A valid TCP/UDP port number. (default: "11211")
The Memcached communication protocol. Valid values are "text" and "binary". (default: "text")
The transport protocol for the connection. Valid values are "tcp", "udp", "connectionOriented", "connectionless". (default: "tcp")
Determines if data compression is used for items sent to the cache. (default: "false")
The algorithm to use for data compression if "useCompression" is set to "true". Valid values are "GZip" and "Deflate". (default: "GZip")
The character encoding of the data sent to the cache. Value values are "ASCII", "BigEndianUnicode", "Unicode", "UTF32", "UTF7", and "UTF8". (default: "UTF8")
The character encoding of the memcached protocol. Valid values are the same as the payloadEncoding attribute. (default: "UTF8")
The number of milliseconds to wait to send data before throwing an exception. (default: 5000)
The number of milliseconds to wait to receive data before throwing an exception. (default: 5000)

member.name: T:Common.Logging.Simple.CommonLoggingTraceListener
member.summary: A implementation sending all System.Diagnostics.Trace output to the Common.Logging infrastructure.
member.remarks:
This listener captures all output sent by calls to System.Diagnostics.Trace and and and sends it to an instance.
The instance to be used is obtained by calling . The name of the logger is created by passing this listener's and any source or category passed into this listener (see or for example).
member.example:
The snippet below shows how to add and configure this listener to your app.config:
<system.diagnostics> <sharedListeners> <add name="Diagnostics" type="Common.Logging.Simple.CommonLoggingTraceListener, Common.Logging" initializeData="DefaultTraceEventType=Information; LoggerNameFormat={listenerName}.{sourceName}"> <filter type="System.Diagnostics.EventTypeFilter" initializeData="Information"/> </add> </sharedListeners> <trace> <listeners> <add name="Diagnostics" /> </listeners> </trace> </system.diagnostics>
member.author: Erich Eichinger
